description:
Labroides dimidiatus, commonly known as the Bluestreak Cleaner Wrasse, is a species of small tropical fish found in the Indo-Pacific region. It belongs to the family Labridae, which includes various species of wrasses.

The Bluestreak Cleaner Wrasse is characterized by its distinctive coloration, with a bright blue dorsal fin and a white or pale yellow ventral region. Its body is elongated and laterally compressed, typical of wrasse species. These fish are known for their unique cleaning behavior, in which they remove ectoparasites and dead skin from the bodies of larger fish, a behavior that benefits both the cleaner and the client fish.

Labroides dimidiatus is considered a keystone species in coral reef ecosystems, playing a crucial role in maintaining the health and diversity of the reef community. Its cleaning services help to control the populations of parasites and promote the overall well-being of the reef-dwelling fishes. These fish are also known to exhibit complex social behaviors, with individuals forming cleaning stations and engaging in intricate interactions with their clients.

Due to their ecological importance and popularity in the aquarium trade, Labroides dimidiatus is a well-studied species, providing valuable insights into the dynamics of coral reef ecosystems and the importance of cleaning symbiosis in marine environments.
